block.p: Camp David Talks Shift to High-Drive Talks at the Camp David peace summit meeting shifted into high-drive as the White House remained officially committed to reaching an agreement between the Israelis and Palestinians before President Clinton departs for Japan tomorrow. But some officials began lowering expectations for a breakthrough.

But some officials began lowering expectations for a breakthrough.

Tycoon Quits Russia Parliament Boris Berezovsky, a Russian tycoon, politician and, until lately, a force in the Kremlin itself, said that he would quit his seat in Parliament and try to form an alliance of big business and regional politicians aimed at curbing President Vladimir V. Putin's growing power.

President Putin arrived in Beijing on the first stop of an Asian tour intended to revive his country's faded diplomatic role in the region and build what could become a Chinese-Russian axis to counter American influence.

Searching for Survivors in Manila Rescuers continued to dig through the remains of a mountain of garbage that collapsed in the Philippines last week, smothering hundreds of squatters. About 200 bodies have been recovered. Residents estimate that up to four times that number may have died.

Assad's Inaugural Speech Bashar al-Assad delivered his inaugural speech as president of Syria. He focused on repairing his country's ailing economy and gave no sign that he would be any more flexible than his late father in negotiating a peace accord with Israel. President Assad officially began a seven-year term after taking the oath of office.

Nazi Slave Labor Compensation The United States and Germany signed an agreement to compensate forced laborers from the Nazi era. German government and industry leaders agreed to contribute equally to a $5 billion fund to compensate the laborers. In exchange, President Clinton pledged that the United States will do what it can to block class-action lawsuits brought against German corporations.

Curbing Violence in Indonesia President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia said he might have to seek international assistance to halt 18 months of sectarian violence in the eastern Maluku Islands, where rogue army units have taken sides in the growing clashes.

Terror Suspect to be Extradited An Algerian indicted in the United States on charges of terrorism waived his right to an extradition hearing in Canada. The suspect, Mokhtar Haouari, will be turned over to the Americans in three weeks.
Trial for Tokyo Subway Attack A Japanese court sentenced two former leaders of a doomsday sect to death for spraying nerve gas in a deadly 1995 attack on the Tokyo subways.

Plans for Regulation Of Cyberspace Surveillance The White House said it would propose legislation to set legal requirements for surveillance in cyberspace by law enforcement authorities similar in some ways to those for telephone wiretaps.
Web Gambling Bill Defeated A coalition of libertarian lawmakers and pro-gambling Internet entrepreneurs defeated a House bill that would have banned gambling on the Internet. The vote was 245 to 159.

400 Sheep to Be Destroyed Agriculture officials plan to destroy nearly 400 Vermont sheep because four of the group, from Belgium, have tested positive for a disorder that may be similar to Europe's mad-cow disease.
Ruling for Medicinal Marijuana A federal judge cleared the way for a group in Oakland, Calif., to distribute marijuana for medicinal purposes.

Clinton's Call Backfires President Clinton's phone call to The New York Daily News to defend Hillary Rodham Clinton from accusations that she used an anti-Semitic slur seems to have backfired. Remarks he made about the summit talks violated a news blackout, while his effort to snuff out the news story about his wife seemed only to add fuel to it.

ABC Changes Course ABC News said that the N.F.L. had agreed to change the starting times of two Monday night preseason games. The move will allow the network to devote an hour of prime time coverage to the opening nights of the party conventions.

Senator Has Brain Surgery Senator Paul Coverdell of Georgia, a Senate Republican leader, underwent brain surgery for a cerebral hemorrhage. The two-hour operation, which relieved pressure caused by the bleeding, was called a success.
Bush on a Running Mate Gov. George W. Bush said for the first time that he was closing in on choosing a running mate.
Gore Closing the Gap Vice President Al Gore called attention to a new CNN/USA Today poll that showed him trailing Gov. George W. Bush by only two points, 43 percent to 45 percent.

Apple Farmers Battered By Economics After Storms Hudson Valley apple growers say they might not recover from two hail storms this spring. Depressed apple prices, spotty insurance coverage and demand for flawless fruit have pushed them to the brink.

More Excess in the Hamptons The Hamptons have never before been invaded by so many rich people wanting to be wowed and wanting it fast. The invasion has driven up construction costs, and seduced builders, architects and even carpenters to build houses on ''spec.''
Officer Dies After Chase An officer pursuing a suspected motorcycle thief died after his unmarked patrol car spun out of control and hit a pole, officials said.
Spraying on Staten Island City officials said they would spray about half of Staten Island with a pesticide starting tomorrow to try to kill mosquitoes that carry the West Nile virus.

2 Accused in Poultry Plot Using forged documents and shipments of chicken legs to Eastern Europe, a father and son from Westchester County with links to Russian organized crime stole more than $35 million from banks and financiers in Latvia and the United States, Manhattan prosecutors said.

Education Chief Threatens Suit New York State's top education official threatened to take Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy to court if he continued to allow uncertified teachers to work in the city's schools.

Plan for Customized Books A deal between IDG Books and an online service, iUniverse, will allow readers to customize books by choosing parts -- chapters, maps and paragraphs -- that can be mixed and matched. The books will be delivered electronically or printed and bound.

Japan Holds on Interest Rates Policy makers at Japan's central bank voted to keep short-term interest rates at virtually zero, concerned about the financial effects of a highly indebted department store company's failure last week.
Paper Company Deal Georgia-Pacific said it would buy the Fort James Corporation in a $7.5-billion transaction, creating the world's largest tissue maker.
Stocks Close Mixed The Dow fell 8.48 points, to 10,804.27; the Nasdaq rose 28.49 points, to 4,274.67, and the S.& P. 500 edged up 0.51 point, to 1,510.49.

Ex-U.S. Attorney Sentenced A federal judge in New Hampshire sentenced a former United States Attorney and commodities regulator to 24 months in prison for becoming a co-conspirator with the operators of fraudulent telemarketing scams.
